April 15, 2015

To Whom It May Concern:

The following are the comments of the Pennsylvania Livestock Marketing Association on the proposed rule regarding Approved Livestock Marketing Facilities (Docket No. APHIS-2014-0018).

We thank you for the chance to provide feedback on the proposed rule. While we appreciate the time and effort taken to update the regulatory scheme surrounding Approved Livestock Marketing Facilities, we feel that USDA missed the mark in components of this proposed rule that reduces ADT rule flexibilities for cattle moving to an Approved Livestock Marketing Facility. The proposal limits the flexibility to only cattle coming to the facility from a Farm of Origin. Additionally, defining Farm of Origin to the farm where livestock are produced or maintained for at least four months prior to movement is unnecessarily broad restricting movement even more.

In Pennsylvania, most of our livestock markets do business with out-of-state customers on a regular basis. This is both a function of being a smaller state and of cattle movement patterns. Additionally, many of our customers selling at market are small producers who bring just one or a few head of cattle to market at a time. For these small producers, it would be extremely expensive to have to have a veterinarian visit the farm to write a health certificate, especially when you consider the fact the cost of this health certificate could only be spread out over a few animals at the most.

This added expense could drive producers to sell at a different market just to avoid crossing state lines. They also may consider selling out of the market environment where it is less likely animal health and livestock movement requirements.

This would lead to less traceability rather than more traceability.

Sincerely,

Pennsylvania Livestock Marketing Association

Dear Mr. Shea,

As the association representing local livestock auction markets in the state of South Carolina, we are writing to provide comments on the proposed rule regarding Approved Livestock Marketing Facilities (Docket No. APHIS-2014-0018).

Generally, we support the comments submitted by Dan Harris, president of the national Livestock Marketing Association. In particular, we share his concerns with the Farm of Origin changes to the ADT rule limiting the feasibility of us continue to do business with our out-of-state customers. Adult cattle coming into our markets are documented and inspected upon arrival, so this adjustment is unnecessary.

We also feel strongly that the agreement should remain in the regulation so markets have the ability to formally comment on any changes just as we are doing now.

In addition, we agree that the language in the proposed agreement should be adjusted so it is clear livestock markets are not solely responsible for all livestock movement and animal health requirements. Our producers, veterinarians, and animal health officials also play an important role.

Our final comment is unique to South Carolina. We have state inspectors that attend each of our livestock auctions. We feel this resource market owners should be able to be utilize, if they chose to do so, to help address the shortage of private veterinarians and increase traceability. This could be accomplished by allowing these state inspectors the ability to write health papers or alternative movement documents to keep livestock moving.

If you have any questions about these comments, please contact John Kissee at 770-596-0128.

South Carolina Livestock Marketing Association
Please see the attached comments from North Carolina LMA.

The industry desperately needs these changes! As a Livestock Market operator in southern Michigan since 1956, we have seen many changes over the years, notably a decrease of Livestock Marketing options. We have several customers from northern Ohio that choose us to market their slaughter cattle. Requiring to have an IVCI issued by a vet for each consignment of slaughter cattle would not only be costly, but not necessary. These cattle go to slaughter and are inspected by USDA at their destination for harvest. To be an "Approved USDA Livestock Facility" to accept out of state slaughter cattle and be required to have a Vet at the site on sale days would serve no purpose. Our local vet on call would allow his/her services on the farms and not pin him/her down at our premise for 6 hours each sale day. These out of state consignments are currently and would be continued to be USDA back tagged, penned separate, not co mingled, and sent from our facilities to slaughter. In addition, they are individually identified with RFID or USDA approved metal ear tags. An "Owner-Shipper" statement to accompany the cattle is no problem for the farmers or truckers. These changes are a step forward to allow livestock marketing across state lines, and will enhance disease traceability.

Randy Heselschwerdt, Napoleon Livestock Commission Co. Napoleon, Michigan

To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing to provide comments on USDAs proposed changes to the Approved Livestock Marketing Facilities and Animal Disease Traceability regulations (Docket No. APHIS-2014-0018).

As the President and CEO of Clovis Livestock Auction, Im concerned about a couple pieces of this proposal. One major concern I have is with the market duties in the proposed Approved Livestock Marketing Facility agreement. To me, it seems USDA would like markets to serve as the police of animal movement requirements. This is a government role that should not be passed on to private businesses. While we work with our buyers and sellers to help them meet requirements by having a veterinarian at our market, enforcing regulations is not a role markets should have to take on. The markets duties in the Approved Livestock Marketing Facility agreement should be adjusted to reflect this.

I also am concerned about the portion of the proposed rule making changes to what is required to bring adult beef cattle and dairy cattle of any age across state lines to an Approved Livestock Marketing Facility. Our auction market is located in eastern New Mexico, close to the Texas border. Due to this, we have many customers crossing state lines to sell or buy cattle.

Under the proposal, out-of-state producers selling cattle 18 months of age or older would have to get a health certificate before bringing these cattle to sell at our market, unless the cattle are coming from the farm where they are born or have been for four months. Getting a veterinarian to visit a farm and write a health certificate can be expensive. In this rule, USDA has recognized that access to large animal veterinarians is a very real problem. My concern is that USDA could be driving customers away from selling out our market by requiring health certificates prior to arrival. This is unnecessary as we have a veterinarian at our market and also record needed traceability information when cattle arrive.

I believe the farm of origin piece of the rule would have a negative impact on my business and put livestock markets that happen to be located close to a state line at a competitive disadvantage. Because of this, my strong recommendation is that USDA does not move forward this component of the proposed rule.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Charlie Rogers

The West Virginia LMA is the trade association of local livestock markets located across West Virginia.

We would like to thank USDA for the work put into this proposal and the opportunity for industry feedback.

There are many positive pieces of the proposal. These include the ability to have veterinarians on call, the use of existing documents as owner shipper statements, and consolidating terminology to the single, more descriptive, term of "approved livestock marketing facilities."

At the same time, there are some pieces that could be improved through adjustments. In particular, the appeals process should be strengthened not weakened. Also, markets should not lose the ability to make formal comments on changes to the requirements listed in the agreement. This right would be lost if the agreement language was taken out of the regulation.

We hope adjustments can be made in these areas.

Sincerely,
West Virginia LMA

RE: Comments regarding Docket No APHIS-2014-0018, Proposed Rule on Livestock Marketing Facilities  
On behalf of the Missouri Department of Agriculture, please consider these comments regarding Docket 
No APHIS-2014-0018, Proposed Rule on Livestock Marketing Facilities. 
Thank you for allowing comments on the proposed rule. Missouri is ranked in the top 10 in many 
livestock categories and currently has 106 state-federal licensed markets.  After careful review of the 
proposed changes, we would like to make the following recommendations and suggestions. 
Proposed Revisions to Part 71 
Currently livestock markets are licensed and approved through a joint cooperative effort of state and 
federal authority; we would hope this relationship would continue in the future.  However, it is unclear 
that this is the intent of the proposed regulations with references to section 8308 of the Animal Health 
Protection Act (AHPA, 7 U.S.C. 8301, et seq.) and the statement “At the discretion of APHIS, a State 
animal health official could also be a cosignatory on the agreement”. Additionally, the Approved 
Livestock Marketing Agreement is stated to be between a livestock marketing facility and APHIS.  It 
appears under the proposed regulations APHIS is extending its authority to livestock market facilities 
that are not federally licensed via their authority under the Animal Health Protection Act.  It would seem 
to be an overreach of federal authority if the facility is not meeting the marketing requirements to be 
federally licensed under 9 CFR 71.20. We sincerely hope this does not set precedence for the utilization 
of the AHPA from this point forward. 
The proposed market agreement gives the impression the state will be engaged in the process. The 
livestock markets are currently licensed in our state by the state department of agriculture under the 
direction of the state veterinarian. However, we will again emphasize the need to keep the state in any 
agreements between APHIS and the livestock markets.   
Proposed Revisions to Part 86 
In Section 86.1, the “farm of origin” is defined as the location of the animals for a period of 4 months 
prior to movement.  How will livestock market owners be able to verify the animals comply with the 
“farm of origin” criteria upon arrival at the livestock market?  Would this mean without verification the 
animals would not qualify to move interstate without an ICVI and official identification to a livestock 
market that is also a “tagging site”? We feel this would be an undue burden on the livestock market 

and/or the accredited veterinarian at the market with little or no way of verification possible other than 
the seller’s word.  
In Section 86.5, we agree with the clarification to allow animals to move interstate to a livestock market 
facility without an ICVI or owner-shipper statement when the livestock market is collecting all the 
necessary information that would normally be captured on a movement document if this is allowed by 
the state of destination. 
Proposed Revisions to the Approved Livestock Marketing Agreement 
We are opposed to the removal of the requirement that an accredited veterinarian, State or APHIS 
representative must be on the premises at all times on sale days to perform duties in accordance with 
State and Federal regulations.  In the event APHIS feels the need no longer exists for a veterinarian to be 
present at the livestock market on sale days, we would like clarity to ensure the state’s authority would 
be recognized.   
We believe the presence of an accredited veterinarian is crucial to ensure the health and welfare of 
animals marketed through the facility.  In addition, it ensures we have individuals who are experts in the 
field of veterinary medicine available to provide early detection of disease in our livestock markets. The 
livestock markets assemble animals from a variety of locations within the United States and co-mingle 
and disperse them throughout the United States after the sale.  To protect the health of our animals it is 
absolutely critical through early detection that we have veterinarians on site to examine animals 
entering into commerce through our livestock markets to enhance or ensure early detection of disease. 
The presence of the accredited veterinarian at our livestock markets ensures that livestock market 
employees are adhering to the federal regulations.  The absence of this individual would leave the 
livestock market owners to self regulate. Would they also be required to self report any variance from 
the federal requirements?  Would APHIS rely on the biannual inspections to ensure compliance?  
Currently in the event of a disease trace, the livestock market veterinarian is relied upon and in many 
cases expected to provide the required information to authorities.  
The lack of veterinarians in certain regions of the United States should not be a driving force to change 
the requirement of an accredited veterinarian to be present in the livestock markets. Instead it should 
enhance the ability of a veterinarian to provide large animal veterinary service to livestock producers in 
the region.  The livestock market veterinarians in our state are paid through the services they provide to 
the livestock producers, thus serve as a means to improve the marketability of the animals and are 
considered an asset to the livestock producers and markets.  In addition, they ensure the livestock 
moving through the livestock market are handled in accordance to current animal handling standards 
accepted by NCBA and BQA Guidelines.  Their presence ensures animals that are injured during 
transport or at the livestock market are dealt with swiftly and humanely to prevent prolonged suffering.

I have been employed by the USDA-APHIS-VS for 36 years as an Animal Health Technician 
and 10 of those years as an Animal Identification Coordinator. I am submitting, for your 
consideration, my comments as a private citizen on the proposed changes to the Livestock 
Marketing Facilities regulations. The Livestock Marketing Facilities regulations continue to 
cause undue hardships to an important entity in the cattle industry, the Licensed Livestock 
Dealer.
I am referencing the statement in the Proposed Rules for Livestock Marketing Facilities 
under “Proposed Revisions to Part 86” paragraph 9:
After reviewing the relevant provisions of the agreement in 71.20 and how they have been 
implemented operationally, we agree with producers and State animal health officials that 
the information maintained by approved livestock marketing facilities for all livestock that 
enter the facility often includes all categories of information that are required on the 
owner-shipper statement. Thus, we are proposing to allow cattle and bison to be moved 
interstate to an approved livestock marketing facility without an accompanying owner-
shipper statement provided a State animal health official has waived the need for the owner-
shipper statement and all of the information required for an owner-shipper statement is 
recorded as soon as the cattle or bison are offloaded at the approved livestock marketing 
facility and this is maintained in accordance with the record retention requirements located 
in 86.3.
A Licensed Livestock Dealer is required by state laws to have a valid livestock dealer 
license in each state that they engage in the business of dealing in cattle. They must identify 
slaughter cattle and keep a record book. This record book contains the same information that 
is required on the owner shipper statement. Every cattle transaction, listing of official ID and 
backtag numbers, the date of purchase, repossessed, sold, traded or loaned, or from whom 
obtained and to whom the cattle are transferred is to be recorded in their dealer record book. 
There is a united concern among License Livestock Dealers that their sources of business and 
income would become public knowledge and jeopardized their business if they are required 
to provide the Livestock Marketing Facilities (LMF) with the names and addresses of the 
farms/producers where they obtain cattle from, as required with the owner-shipper statement 
regulations. By requiring the dealers to provide this information to the Livestock Marketing 
Facilities they are providing important confidential information to potential competitors, with 
no added benefit to the traceability system.

Final comments:
I propose that the requirement of the owner-shipper statement be modified so that the owner 
shipper statement does not require the name and address of where the animals originate for 
licensed livestock dealers. The LMF would be responsible for maintaining a record of which 
licensed livestock dealer delivered the animals to the LMF. The traceability can then be 
completed by using the licensed dealer records.
I respectfully submit for your consideration,

director has statutory authority to appoint a veterinarian, subject to board approval, as an 
authorized veterinarian for livestock markets. The proposed rule changes for livestock marketing 
facilities are of interest to the board and to me since we share the responsibility of maintaining 
the health and protecting the ownership of Wyoming livestock.
The following comments express our concerns, questions, and suggestions to the draft 
proposal:
Section 71.1 Definition - The definition of “Approved Livestock Marketing Facility” 
should include language consistent with that in the definition of “Livestock Marketing Facility” 
by adding the words, “for sale or sale purposes,” between “assembled” and “and that has been 
approved under §71.20.”
In the paragraph, “Application of USDA Approved Back tags,” it is important to consider 
both the retention of the backtag and the safety of the person who is responsible for applying the 
tag. Both are of paramount importance. Also of significant importance is back tag collection at 
slaughter so recovery of the tag must also be highly considered. For best retention and recovery, 
we recommend that the back tag be placed on the dorsum at the level of the last thoracic 
vertebrae. APHIS should cooperate with FSIS to provide a tool that will retrieve a back tag if it 
is beyond the reach of personnel on the slaughter line.

retention rate” as a requirement for the facility permit.

Re: Comments on Docket No. 2014 -0018; Proposed Rule for Livestock Marketing Facilities

The Texas Animal Health Commission (TAHC) is providing comments regarding the regulation proposal by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) for Livestock Marketing Facilities. This regulation proposal contains requirements that affect the Cooperative State-Federal programs to control or eradicate diseases of livestock as well as requirements for the interstate movement of livestock to a livestock marketing facility.

1.) TAHC is supportive of USDA efforts to make regulation more consistent in terminology and well as with the interface with other regulatory programs and particularly for the purpose making animal disease traceability more effective.
2.) TAHC supports the defining of farm of origin as any farm where livestock are held or maintained for at least four (4) consecutive months.
3.) TAHC agrees that an owner-shipper statement applies only to cattle and bison moved interstate from their farm of origin to an approved livestock marketing facility.
4.) TAHC is also supportive of allowing cattle and bison to be moved interstate to an approved livestock marketing facility without an accompanying owner-shipper statement, provided all of the information required for an owner-shipper statement is recorded as soon as the cattle or bison are offloaded at the approved livestock marketing facility and the records are maintained in accordance with the record retention requirements.
5.) TAHC supports the limited use of owner shipper statements to the specific standards established in the rule proposal.
6.) TAHC would specifically request that USDA specify that backtags be applied at the dorsal midline behind shoulder and no farther back than last T vertebrae as TAHC believes it will facilitate their removal more efficiently at slaughter.
7.) TAHC urges USDA-APHIS to work with USDA FSIS to ensure that backtags are collected along with all other official identification collected at slaughter.

To whom it may concern,

I am a law student in my final year of law school at Nova Southeastern University in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Your proposed rule stood out to me as I had previously taken an animal law seminar in which I wrote a paper focusing, in part, on the interstate transportation of rodeo broncs. In doing so, I spoke about the federal Twenty-Eight Hour Law (49 USC 80502) as well as the regulations adopted by the United States Department of Agriculture as mentioned in 9 C.F.R. 89. Noticing that your proposed rule overlaps with much of research I encountered in writing my paper, I would offer the following comments as to the proposed revision to Part 71.
I understand the practicality of your decision to revise 71.20 as simply requiring a veterinarian on-call rather than on the premise at all times, however I am concern that the language in this section is too board as to who determines whether an animal may need an interstate certificate of veterinary inspection (ICVI) before leaving the facility after sale. For example, should this determinate be left up to someone who profits financially from having these animals shipped to another facility despite their health conditions, I have serious concerns for its vague phrasing.
Further, the restatement in 71.20(a) of 8303 of the Animal Health Protection Act (AHPA, 7 U.S.C. 8301 et seq.) stating that APHIS may carry out operations and measures to control, or eradicate any pest or disease of livestock also seems rather ambiguous. I understand that should pests or disease be detected in livestock, there is a strong health and safety interest in having them eradicated, however being a strong animal welfare advocate I would simply ask that this be done as humanely as possible by adding said language to your restatement.

Sincerely,
Jennifer Trunk

Not sure if this relates directly to the proposed changes, but two points:

1) The ADT Rule has created a potential "traceability loophole" in allowing cattle to move interstate to an approved tagging site with no ID and no CVI. This should happen only if the receiving tagging site is required to tag with official ID and maintain records in such a manner that animals are traceable back to the state and ship-from location. For example, Virginia allows breeding age cattle to be imported with no ID and no CVI if they are moving to an approved market and tagging site in VA, but they require that cattle are tagged with 840 RFID and usually a back tag that can be correlated with seller/buyer records in market files. The 840 tag provides traceability going forward; the back tag provides backward traceability.

2) It is difficult to get dairy calves/steers tagged with official ear tags at Virginia markets due to number of animals handled. If these animals are moving to other states in a fairly direct manner (similar to cull cattle), back tags may provide adequate traceability if correlated with seller/buyer records on both ends (shipping and receiving locations). Current back tags could (if appropriate) also be scanned with bar code readers to improve efficiency and accuracy of data capture. For example, dairy calves/steers in VA tagged with back tags and correlated to seller/buyer records; animals could be tagged with ear tags in receiving state, which should be correlated with VA back tags. Back tags are cheap, unique when paired with a date and location, stay on fairly well for short-term movements and are easier to capture than metal tags.

The Virginia Livestock Marketing Association supports the comment of the LMA on this proposed rule. Please see these comments attached as reference.

Thank you.

RE: Docket No. APHIS-2014-0018, Proposed Rule on Livestock Marketing Facilities 
On behalf of The Humane Society of the United States and our members and supporters, thank 
you for the opportunity to submit public comment in response to the proposed rule regarding 
regulations governing approval of facilities that receive livestock moved in interstate commerce.  
These comments address the proposal to amend the Approved Livestock Marketing Facility 
Agreement under §71.20 to remove the requirement that an accredited veterinarian, State 
representative, or APHIS representative must be on the premises at all times on sale days.1 
The Federal Register Notice states that the requirement should be removed because when the 
rule was established, communicable livestock diseases were more prevalent in the United States, 
and it was more crucial for a veterinarian, APHIS Representative, or State representative to be on 
site to process paperwork, conduct testing, and ensure the isolation of high-risk livestock to 
prevent disease transmission.  However, communicable livestock diseases certainly still exist.2 In 
fact, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations describes animal 
transport as “ideally suited for spreading disease,” given that animals may originate from 
different herds or flocks and are “confined together for long periods in a poorly ventilated 
stressful environment.”33   The presence of a veterinarian or state/APHIS representative has 
utility beyond completing paperwork.  These individuals are qualified to identify problems and 
evaluate risks at livestock marketing facilities before they become larger problems. 
The HSUS urges APHIS to consider how susceptible livestock being moved through livestock 
marketing facilities are, not only to communicable disease, but to stress, injury, and inhumane 
treatment.  Veterinarians in particular are uniquely situated to intervene at livestock marketing 
facilities if needed to protect the safety of the food supply, or the well-being of animals at the 
facilities. 
                                                           
1 80 Fed. Reg. 6-13 (Jan. 2, 2015), http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/granule/FR-2015-01-02/2014-30752 
2 See Attachment 1, examples of recent livestock disease instances. 
3 Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Animal Production and Health Paper 153: Improved 
Animal Health for Poverty Reduction and Sustainable Livelihoods at 5 (2002), 
http://www.fao.org/docrep/005/y3542e/y3542e00.htm. 

Page 2 of 3 
ASPCA, HSUS Re: Docket No. APHIS-2014-0018 
Operators of a livestock marketing facility have a financial stake in the animals at the facility, 
which could lead to under-reporting of animal disease.  Laypersons are also much less qualified 
to make a determination that an animal presents a disease risk than veterinarians or state/APHIS 
representatives. By transferring authority over inspecting livestock for diseases from 
state/APHIS representatives or veterinarians to individuals operating livestock marketing 
facilities, the proposed rule opens the door to potential conflicts of interest that put public and 
animal health at risk.  
Cost savings are not a sufficient justification for the increased threats to public health and animal 
health and welfare that this proposed rule presents.  APHIS should retain the requirement in the 
Approved Livestock Marketing Facility Agreement that a veterinarian, State representative, or 
APHIS representative be present at livestock marketing facilities during sale hours.  Failure to 
retain this requirement could amount to a violation of 7 U.S.C. 8301(5)(B), and thus subject the 
agency to potential litigation under the Administrative Procedure Act.  7 U.S.C. 8301(5)(B) is 
the authorizing legislation for 9 C.F.R. 71.2, and tasks APHIS with the duty “to protect the 
agriculture, environment, economy, and health and welfare of the people of the United States.”  7 
U.S.C. 8301(5)(B).  Failure to require a veterinarian, State representative, or APHIS 
representative to be present during operating hours would pose harm to health and welfare of the 
animals and the safety of the food chain.  
Particularly as APHIS proposes to change other requirements for transport and identification in 
this proposed rule, the supervision of a veterinarian or state or APHIS representative could prove 
invaluable in ensuring that APHIS-approved livestock marketing facilities represent safe 
facilities with sufficient oversight to ensure the safety of the animals moving through them and 
the safety of the agricultural economies that depend on them. 
 
Thank you for your consideration of these comments.  Respectfully submitted, 
 
 
Jennifer Lonergan 
Regulatory Affairs Specialist 
The Humane Society of the United States

I am writing for the Indiana State Board of Animal Health (BOAH) to comment on the proposed 
rule governing livestock market facilities, docket number APHIS-2014-0018. 
Veterinarians at Markets 
The proposed rule would allow approved livestock marketing facilities to have a veterinarian on

BOAH supports this change. Many markets in Indiana are unable to find a veterinarian that is 
willing to be at the market for an entire sale, just in case a certificate of veterinary inspection is 
needed. Allowing markets to have an on-call arrangement with a veterinarian is a reasonable 
approach to accommodate the reality of the veterinary services market and meet the federal 
animal disease traceability rule requirements. 
Cattle and Bison Moved to Markets 
The proposed rule seeks to clarify that cattle and bison may be moved interstate to a market 
without identification if they are moved from the farm of origin to a market and the market 
applies the identification. 9 CFR 86.4. Cattle and bison may not be moved from one market 
interstate to another market without ID. The first market must ID the animals before they are 
moved interstate to another market. BOAH supports this proposed clarification. 
The proposed rule seeks to clarify that animals may be moved interstate to a market without a 
certification of veterinary inspection (CVI) if they are moved from the farm of origin to an 
approved livestock marketing facility. 9 CFR 86.5. Cattle and bison may not be moved from a 
market interstate to another market without a CVI. The first market must provide a CVI for 
interstate movement. BOAH 
supports this proposed clarification. 
Page 11 

Calves 
The current traceability rule allows movement of sexually intact beef calves under 18 months of 
age without listing each identification individually on the CVI. This exception does not apply to 
sexually intact dairy cattle of any age. 9 CFR 86.5( c )(7). BOAH believes that the rule should be 
amended to allow movement of sexually intact dairy bull calves under 18 months of age with 
identification on a CVI that does not list each of the identification individually. 
Many dairy calves move through livestock markets in a manner similar to beef calves. Reading 
tags in the ears of dairy bull calves as they move through a market can be very difficult and time 
consuming. BOAH believes it is important that these animals be tagged with official 
identification. However once 
the animals are tagged, sufficient traceability for the dairy bull 
calves can be maintained with a CVI that does not list each animal individually. 
Backtags on Slaughter Animals 
In the first paragraph of proposed revisions to Part 86, it states that cattle or bison may be moved 
through no more than one approved livestock marketing facility and then directly to a recognized 
slaughtering establishment. The language implies that the back tag may be applied at the 
recognized slaughtering establishment. We disagree with allowing cattle or bison moving 
through a livestock marketing facility to be back tagged at the recognized slaughtering facility. 
These animals should be back tagged at the approved livestock marketing facility before moving 
to slaughter. Any cattle or bison moving through a market should be tagged before there is any 
chance of commingling, loss of origin identity, or leaving the first market. BOAH still supports 
allowing tags to be applied at the slaughter facility for movements directly from the 
farm of 
origin to a recognized slaughtering facility without any commingling. 
Application of RFID 840 Tags 
BOAH supports the limitation in the current rule prohibiting application of more than one 
official identification device or method to an animal. BOAH supports the exception provided for 
the application of 840 prefix identification to animals already officially identified with a National 
Uniform Eartagging System (NEUS) tag. 9 CFR 86.3(c)(3). But, BOAH believes this exception 
should be broadened to allow the application of 840 prefix radio frequency identification (RFID) 
tag to an animal that is already identified with a non-RFID 840 prefix tag. A non-RFID tag is 
incompatible with a system that relies on RFID tags to function, such as wand or panel readers at 
markets and many dairy management systems. With more livestock markets embracing EID 
reader technology and more dairy farms using EID for cow management, the rule should 
accommodate a market or farmer's effort to improve technology in identification and data 
capture by allowing the application of an RFID tag. 
Thank you for considering these comments. 
Sincerely,

National Pork Producers Council’s Comments Regarding Docket No. APHIS–2014–0018: Livestock Marketing Facilities     The National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) is an association of 43 state pork producer organizations that serves as the voice in Washington for the nation’s pork producers.  The U.S. pork industry represents a significant value-added activity in the agriculture economy and the overall U.S. economy.  Nationwide more than 68,000 pork producers marketed more than 117 million hogs in 2013, and those animals provided total gross receipts of more than $23.4 billion.  Overall, an estimated $22.3 billion of personal income and $39 billion of gross national product are supported by the U.S. hog industry.  After careful review and input from subject-matter experts, NPPC submits the following comments regarding USDA APHIS’s proposed rule for Livestock Marketing Facilities.  It is our understanding that the intent of this rule is to update the regulations governing Livestock Marketing Facilities and to ensure the traceability of livestock that are moved in interstate commerce to and from such facilities.  In the Proposed Revisions to Part 86, USDA is proposing to define “farm of origin” in § 86.1 as ‘‘any farm where livestock are produced, or any farm on which they are maintained for at least 4 consecutive months prior to interstate movement.” If published as written, this definition would apply to all livestock covered under the ADT rule.   This proposed definition is in conflict with 9 CFR Part 85 Pseudorabies, Section § 85.1 of which defines “farm of origin” as “A farm where the swine were born, or on which they have resided for at least 90 consecutive days immediately prior to the interstate shipment.”   NPPC suggests that the Proposed Revision to Part 86 definition of “farm of origin” should include language that specifies it only applies to cattle and bison.  Alternatively, the proposed rule could provide a definitive statement that for swine the definition of “farm of origin” in 9 CFR Part 85 Pseudorabies, Section § 85.1 takes precedence over the definition of “farm of origin” in the rule. Dear Sir or Madam: 
  
The Ranchers-Cattlemen Action Legal Fund, United St ockgrowers of America (R-CALF USA) 
appreciates this opportunity to submit comments to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) 
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) regarding the agency’s proposed rule: 
Livestock Marketing Facilities  (Proposed Rule), published at 80 Fed. Reg. 6-13 (J an. 2, 2015) 
and 80 Fed. Reg. 16,593-594 (March 30, 2015) (reopening of comment period). 
 
Among other things, the Proposed Rule would relax requirements under the regulations in 9 CFR 
part 86, “Animal Disease Traceability” (ADT) by no longer requiring an accredited veterinarian, 
State representative, or APHIS representative be on the premises of a livestock marketing facility 
on sale days and by allowing adult cattle and bison , under certain circumstances, to be moved 
interstate without an accompanying owner-shipper statement.  
 
R-CALF USA contends that the federally mandated ADT  represents government overreach, is 
unnecessarily intrusive, and its stated objectives would be better accomplished if left to 
individual states and tribes. Therefore, any relaxa tions of the ADT’s requirements are viewed by 
R-CALF USA as favorable improvements.  
 
It is noteworthy that R-CALF USA members are concer ned with the increasing scarcity of 
accredited large animal veterinarians across the na tion, which is symptomatic of our industry’s 
fast shrinking marketing outlets. This shrinkage is the result of the ongoing vertical integration of 
the U.S. cattle industry by oligopolistic meatpacke rs and is being facilitated by the Department 
of Justice’s and USDA’s inadequate enforcement of U .S. antitrust laws and the Packers and 
Stockyards Act. Consequently, there are now far few er cattle feeders, far fewer cow/calf 
producers and far fewer cattle than there were just  a decade or so ago. Hence, there are now 
fewer economic opportunities for large animal veterinarians.

Perhaps this is the reason for the aforementioned p roposed relaxations of the ADT requirements. 
It appears the U.S. cattle industry has already shr unk to a level where it is no longer 
economically feasible to rely on the dwindling pool of available veterinarians.  
 
R-CALF USA recommends that APHIS relax an additiona l and related requirement under the 
ADT that, like the Proposed Rule, would reduce the need to rely on large animal veterinarians to 
perform a redundant service that the ADT now requires at livestock marketing facilities. 
 
Under current regulations, a group of adult cattle offloaded at a livestock marketing facility are 
required to be run through a chute to be individual ly identified and their official identification 
numbers individually recorded by the attending vete rinarian prior to sale if they did not already 
arrive with such accompanying documentation.  It is  common for individual cattle within such a 
group of cattle to be sold to more than one buyer a t the livestock marketing facility. Presently, 
before these same cattle that had already been identified and recorded as a group prior to entering 
the sale ring can be loaded for shipment to differe nt out-of-state destinations, they must again be 
run through a chute to have their individual identi fication numbers read and recorded, and the 
resulting new documentation then accompanies the cattle to their new destinations. 
 
The requirement that individual cattle identified a nd recorded in a group must be re-recorded on 
separate documents when the group is dispersed to d ifferent out-of-state destinations is an 
unnecessary burden on livestock marketing facilitie s and their attending large animal 
veterinarians. To remedy this, R-CALF USA recommend s that each group of cattle dispersed 
interstate from the original group should be allowe d to travel accompanied by a copy of the list 
of the original group’s identification numbers. 
 
For clarity, R-CALF USA proposes this:  If cattle w ith numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4 arrive at the 
livestock marketing facility, the interstate certif icate of veterinary inspection (ICVI) will list 
numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4.  If each animal is then sold  to a different out-of-state buyer, then four 
copies of the original ICVI should be made and each  individual animal would then travel 
interstate accompanied by a copy of the original ICVI that includes all four animals.   
      
This streamlining of current paperwork requirements  will not interfere with interstate disease 
tracebacks. Instead, it will help to expedite any p otential disease investigation. This is because 
animal health officials, when reviewing the documen tation accompanying a potential disease 
suspect, will have immediate access not only to whe re the individual animal originated, but also, 
which other animals had left the same farm of origin at the same time as the suspect animal.   
 
R-CALF USA encourages APHIS to adopt this recommend ed change when it promulgates its 
final rule as doing so will eliminate unnecessary b urdens on livestock marketing facilities and 
their attending large animal veterinarians and will help to expedite potential disease tracebacks. 
 
Sincerely, 
 
Bill Bullard, CEO

broad regulatory authority over the manufacture, sale, and marketing of tobacco products.  One of the fundamental

and implement an effective multicultural youth tobacco prevention campaign.  Media tracking and evaluation studies are 
important public health tools and are used regularly to assess and improve public education campaigns, and the methods 
proposed are standard ones.  The results will inform FDA efforts both during the campaign and for potential subsequent 
campaigns.

On behalf of the Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe, I am pleased to respond to your request 
for comments on the proposed rule published by the Department of Interior that would 
revise current regulations at 25 CFR 256, Housing Improvement Program.  The 
Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe (the “Tribe”) is a federally recognized Tribe whose lands are 
located on the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State.  Our Tribe seeks to be self -
sufficient and provide quality governmental programs and services that address the 
unique social, cultural, natural resource and economic needs of its citizens.  
Our Tribe operates a BIA Housing Improvement Program under 25 CFR 256, to assist 
needy Tribal citizens and Indian families living within our Tribal service area who have 
no other recourse for decent, safe and sanitary housing.  The proposed rule would 
update various provisions that will align the HIP Program with other Federal program 
income requirements, provide flexibility for Tribes to better address large waiting lists in 
their service areas, foster relationships with other Federal agencies on ways to leverage 
Federal housing funds, improve sustainable affordable housing on Tribal lands, 
Increase the number of Tribal citizens/ Indian families served and, increase the number 
of projects funded. We therefore appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this 
matter.


Comments on Proposed Rule Revising 25 CFR 256
Housing Improvement Program
March 6, 2015 Page 2
General Comments: 
Category A – Repair of Existing Homes
 The proposed rule would increase the limit for Category A Funding from $2,500 
to $7,500.  We are in favor of the proposed increase to the funding limits as it 
would allow us to address more housing conditions that threaten the health 
and/or safety of our Tribal citizens/Indian families that reside in our service area.  
The current repair limits are inadequate because they do not reflect the average 
costs of housing repairs.   
Category B – Renovation Limits
 The proposed rule would increase the limit for Category B Funding from $35,000 
to $60,000 and Increase the Payback Agreement period from 5 years to 10 
years.  We are in favor of the proposed increase to the renovation limits as it 
would allow us to comply with applicable Tribal building code standards.  The 
current renovation limits are inadequate because they fail to provide adequate 
funding to improve housing conditions to a level that meets applicable building 
code standards.  We are also in favor of increasing the Payback Agreement 
period due to the fact that we will be investing almost twice as much money for 
home renovations and want to ensure that we will recoup the entire amount of 
funds invested or a portion thereof if the recipient sells the home.  The money we 
recoup could be used to address the housing needs of other HIP program 
applicants on our current waiting list.
Category D – Down Payment Assistance
 We are in favor of the new provision, Category D – Down Payment Assistance, 
which would allow us to leverage USDA Direct Loans and HUD Section 184 
Loans.  If we are able to leverage federal dollars from these other housing loan 
programs, we will be able to serve Tribal citizens/Indian families who would not 
otherwise qualify for housing because they do not have the financial resources to 
come up with a down payment.  Our working class Tribal members use their 
limited income for essential needs and cannot afford to save enough money to 
move into permanent housing.  Down payment assistance dollars could be used 
to buy down the interest rate and principle loan so that monthly mortgage 
payments are affordable for working Tribal families.

USET is a non-profit, inter-Tribal organization representing 26 federally recognized Indian Tribes from Texas across to Florida and up to Maine. USET appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the Proposed Rule and looks forward to the opportunity to provide additional input as rulemaking proceeds. Should you have questions or require additional information please do not hesitate to contact Ms. Liz Malerba, USET Director of Policy and Legislative Affairs, at (202)-624-3550 or by e-mail at Lmalerba@usetinc.org.

March 6, 2015

VIA ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION
Bureau of Indian Affairs
Attn:Elizabeth Appel, Director, Office of Regulatory Affairs & Collaborative Action

Subject:Comments on Proposed Amendments to Housing Improvement Program, Docket Nos. BIA-2014-0004

My name is Christina Sturdevant and I am a first year law student in California.

First, the proposed amendment to the Housing Improvement Program that will increase the income guidelines fits squarely within the Bureau of Indian Affairs mission. The Bureau of Indian Affairs mission is to enhance the quality of life, promote economic opportunity, and to carry out the responsibility to protect and improve the trust assets of American Indians, Indian tribes, and Alaska Natives. If the income guidelines are increased from 125 percent to 150 percent of the federal poverty level, more American Indian and Alaska Native families will be eligible for the housing improvement grants. Individuals living at 150 percent of the federal poverty level, while slightly more advantaged than those living at 125 percent of the poverty level, still require adequate housing conditions. The increase of 25 percent will allow families who do not have financial resources to repair or renovate their existing homes.

Second, the Act should be amended to increase the monetary limit of funding granted to Category A and Category B recipients. Category A and Category B recipients currently receive a maximum of $2,500 to repair or renovate their homes. As stated in the proposal, this amount is inadequate to create material changes to the existing homes of impoverished families. Of course, any funding creates a dent, but $2,500 is unlikely to make any lasting improvements. For example, re-carpeting a small apartment costs at least $1,000. Surely, the Bureau of Indian Affairs mission to enhance the quality of life of American Indians, Indian tribes, and Alaska Natives is only minimally carried out by such a small repair. While an apartment may be re-carpeted, there might be termite damage (several thousands of dollars to repair), water damage, and any host of costly repairs that need fixing. A grant of merely $2,500 simply is not enough to truly enhance the quality of life of these families. Further, these amendments will advance the requirements of 25 U.S.C. 13, which state that, the Bureau of Indian affairs use money appropriated to them by Congress to assist in the relief of distress and conservation of health of Indians throughout the United States. This proposed amendment would improve the health of impoverished Native American families by improving basic needs. For example, water damage can lead to mold, bed bugs can lead to a host of health issues and unfit housing conditions contribute to a host of mental illnesses. Therefore, the act should be amended to reflect the proposal of an increase from $2,500 to $7,500.

Finally, the proposal to amend the payback period for Category B grant recipients from five years to ten years should not be implemented because it is coercive and places an undue burden on recipients of the grants. Payback agreements require recipients to pay back the entire amount of funding received or a portion thereof if the recipient sell a home repaired or renovated with grant money within a certain period of time. Currently, that period of time is set at five years. The proposal is to amend that period to ten years. This increase will detrimentally affect the life opportunities of grant recipients because they will be constrained by the requirement that they stay in their home for at least ten years. This will greatly impair the abilities of families who may in the future decide to seek job opportunities far from home. Of course, part of the Bureau of Indian Affairs mission is to increase the economic opportunities of Native American, and Alaska Native families. The requirement that families who took advantage of the opportunity to improve their homes, and better their lives, will limit their economic opportunities long term. For example, it is conceivable that five years from repairing ones home, a grant recipient who has been unable to find employment learns about greater job opportunities in another locality or state. This individual will be constrained by the requirement not to sell their home because they will have to pay back the amount of funding they received five years prior. While the individual will have a home that is hospitable, he or she will not also have the resources that come with a recurring paycheck. Therefore, the proposed amendment to the Category B payback period is an impediment to future economic opportunities of grant recipients and should not be implemented.

Respectfully submitted,

Christina Sturdevant

Regarding the ranking factor of Annual Household Income, and the change of 125% to 150%, I would recommend increasing further, to 175%. This would allow for the people deepest in poverty to get ahead on the list, so that they can get their housing repaired/improved faster. These people deep in poverty need it especially, so that they have a reliable place to stay as they start to climb out of poverty.

Re: Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) Proposed Rule for the Housing Improvement Program 
(HIP) 
Dear Ms. Appel: 
These comments, on the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) Proposed Rule for the Housing 
Improvement Program (HIP), are submitted by the Spokane Indian Housing Authority, located 
on the Spokane Reservation in Eastern Washington State. 
First, and probably most important, the Spokane Indian Housing Authority joins with 
other tribes/TDHEs/tribal organizations to urge BIA and the Administration to seek a significant 
increase in appropriations to fund HIP and to increase the focus in the BIA on this program. HIP 
rightly targets a part of the population that is in dire need of such support. HIP has had a 
significant impact in the lives of Indian people, but over the years the amount of funding in real 
dollars has dropped substantially. The result has been to limit the effectiveness of the program. 
As you know, there have been a great deal of news coverage lately about the importance of 
"housing first" in addressing a variety of social ills - unemployment, crime, drug and alcohol 
abuse-that we see in Indian Country. HIP has the potential to ensure that some of the lowest 
income Indian families can maintain their homes and avoid homelessness or overcrowding, but 
to reach that potential it must be funded at a sufficient level. 
We join with other tribes/TDHEs/tribal organizations in supporting the value of the HIP 
program, the Department of Interior (DOl) and the BIA to work with Congress to fund the 
program at a meaningful level that can actually meet existing needs in Indian Country. The 
Spokane Indian Housing Authority supports the BIA's overall intent in the Proposed Rule to 
provide greater flexibility in the implementation of the HIP, more effective priorities for funding, 
higher limits for allowable costs, and longer active period for pending applications, among other 
developments. As noted in the comments below, however, the Spokane Indian Housing 
Authority also has recommendations for further improvements for the Proposed Rule. 
• §256.7 of the Proposed Rule and Increase in Amounts:

• The increase in amounts for Category A funding for interim improvement assistance up 
to $7500 (from the previous $2500) is an appropriate and positive change, particularly 
with the explicit allowance of freight costs. We recommend, though, that the BIA revisit 
this amount within 2-3 years, rather than the lengthy time that lapsed prior to the 
Proposed Rule, to make certain this amount is sufficient. 
• The increase in amounts for Category B funding for renovation assistance up to 
$60,000 (from the previous $35,000) is an appropriate and positive change, particularly 
with the explicit allowance of freight costs. We recommend, though, that the BIA revisit 
this amount within 2-3 years, rather than the lengthy time that lapsed prior to the 
Proposed Rule, to make certain this amount is sufficient. 
• The addition of a new category of down payment assistance as Category D is another 
welcome addition to the HIP program, though we recommend that the definition of 
"standard housing condition" in § 256.2(1) should state that construction conforms to 
codes "and/or to appropriate building standards for the region where no such codes 
exist." We note that in rural areas and in certain areas in Indian Country, there are 
circumstances where building codes do not always match up, or keep pace with best 
practices in building standards. Adding the above underlined language would 
acknowledge this regional difference. 
• §256.9-Category B Assistance. 
We recommend that §256.9(d)(2) be revised to be consistent with the ISDEAA 1, 
NAHASDA 2, and the practice of self-governance by many tribes, TDHEs, and tribal 
organizations operating the HIP program. That revision would read as follows: 
"At the time of settlement of the sale of the house, you will repay the tribe, Tribally 
Designated Housing Entity, or tribal organization directly operating the HIP Program or 
the BIA the full cost of all renovations made under this part." 
This change would then allow for the HIP funding, if it is returned in the 1 0 years 
following completion of repairs and renovation, to stay directly within the community where it 
was originally invested, consistent with the intent of ISDEAA, NAHASDA, and the self­
governance movement. Otherwise, a return of funding to the BIA could result in unnecessary 
delay, red-tape, and/or return to the Treasury and out of the realm of meeting tribal housing 
needs.

Re: Comment Letter on Proposed Housing Improvement Program Regulation Amendments

Dear Ms. Appel:
As Executive Director of the Cheyenne River Housing Authority I am hereby submitting comments on the proposed Housing Improvement Program Regulation Amendments.

Addition of Category D Adding this new category of housing will help Tribes promote the benefits of homeownership to families of all ages. The down payment assistance funds will help Native American families qualify for homeownership financing. Since this is a new category and expands the allowable HIP Programs housing assistance funds and services there should be clarification that these funds may be used for: down payment assistance, closing costs, education in financial literacy and homebuyer education and counseling.
oIncome Eligibility for Category D In order to insure that the HIP down payment assistance is available to families who can afford mortgage financing, we recommend that income eligibility be defined for Category D by using the definition provided by the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act (NAHASDA) regulations. This would allow eligibility by participants with annual income that is 80 percent of the area median income or United States median income, whichever is higher. (12 CFR 1000.10)

oPrevious Assistance While we recognize the need to serve clients who have not previously received assistance through the HIP program, we recommend that the restriction from being eligible for the HIP down payment program not apply to recipients of Category B rehabilitation funds if the funds were received prior to a certain time, e.g. more than 25 years ago (proposed Section 256.6 (g)).

oSet-Aside In order to promote the use of the down payment assistance program, we recommend that 10 percent of each Regions HIP allocation be set-aside for Category D. If the funds are not expended by the end of the fiscal year, they could be reprogrammed for other HIP categories. It is important to document need for Category D so future appropriation requests can be increased to meet the need to assist Native American families with down payment assistance.

Ranking Factors I support adding the new ranking factors of homelessness, overcrowding, and dilapidated housing will help identify the housing needs of the poorest of the poor. As the need for safe, sanitary and affordable housing increases it is very important to document the need (funded and unfunded) for all categories so future appropriation requests can be increased to provide adequate allocations to Tribes, especially those who have the highest poverty conditions, address their housing shortage.

Advisory Committee for Handbook I recommend that the Bureau to create an Advisory Committee made up of representatives from Tribes, TDHEs, current HIP Directors, Native CDFIs, and other lenders to provide input during the development of the HIP Handbook that will provide guidance for HIP implementation.

Participation in Federal Government-Sponsored Housing The restriction against acquiring your present housing through participation in a Federal government-sponsored housing program (proposed Section 256.6 (h)) should deleted because it is unclear and could possibly unnecessarily limit participation. For example, would an applicant be eligible if he or she obtained their home through a Mutual Help or rent-to-own program, HUD Section 184, or RD Section 502? We dont think participation in any of these programs should restrict participation in HIP, especially Category D.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on the Housing Improvement Programs proposed program regulation amendments. It is encouraging to see proposed changes that will have a positive impact on the eligible Native American families. I am available to answer any questions or provide additional information regarding my comments.

Respectfully,

Sharon Vogel, Executive Director

Dear BOEM Officials:

Thank you for this opportunity to comment on the Environmental Assessment (EA) for the Virginia Offshore Wind Technology Project (VOWTAP). While I support Dominion's two test turbine project, such development must be done in a way that ensures robust protections for marine mammals and sea turtles, in particular for the North American right whale (NARW).

In order to support a Finding of No Significant Issues (FONSI), BOEM must amend the final EA to include the following measures:
prohibit pile-driving during the NARWs peak migratory season from Nov. 1 to April 30
during that time, place a uniform 10-knot speed limit restriction on all vessels of any length affiliated with the VOWTAP project
provide for a minimum of four qualified observers located at the pile driving site
require the developer to use the best commercially available technology to reduce noise associated with construction of the VOWTAP project

I applaud BOEM's efforts to bring clean renewable offshore wind power online as soon as possible. The crisis we face with climate change demands it. Executive Summary  
 
Wind resource evaluation can benefit from new insights into the fundamental physical mechanisms 
responsible for variability across the rotor span, the boundary layer, and the entire region, including the 
Maryland Wind Energy Area (WEA).  This report describes how data from a variety of in-situ and 
remote sensing instruments including Lidar are being used to characterize processes in the atmosphere 
and ocean and improve their representation in simulation models.  This report also documents the 
development of a new Lidar Motion Compensation Algorithm (MCA) for vessels underway.  
 
Floating Lidar technology has the potential to replace met towers in many cases, once accepted by the 
industry.  However, current systems are integrated into floating buoys and incorporate proprietary 
MCAs, which are all designed for motion of an anchored buoy.  By developing and validating an 
algorithm that can be applied to a Lidar unit on a moving vessel,  the UMBC MCA is opening the range 
of deployment possibilities to an entirely new set of platforms.   Many types of vessels that could serve 
as Lidar platforms traverse in or near the MD WEA on a daily basis.   During WEA survey and 
construction operations,  vessels could be continuously collecting wind profile data for use in 
configuring and nudging forecast models, and fine-tuning production estimates.   The cost of lidar units 
will come down significantly as technology improves and economies of scale are realized.   Eventually, 
commercial vessels may be equipped with wind Lidar profilers and the data used in forecasting models,  
just as is often done with marine weather radar data from ships.  The preliminary validation indicates 
that the UMBC MCA has nearly identical error and uncertainty characteristics to the internal, 
proprietary Leosphere MCA used by the WindCube.  The next stage of the analysis is to use the 
Forward Model Algorithm to test the MCA under simulated wind fields and vessel speeds and motions.  
This is currently underway and an update will be provided in the next quarterly report.    
 
In the absence of strong synoptic forcing, smaller scale regional mechanisms in the Mid-Atlantic are 
revealed.  These have the potential to generate locally strong winds that may coincide with high grid 
loads [1,2 ].  Satellite sea surface temperature data often shows cool water upwelling along the coast, 
creating a low-level local baroclinic zone and changing the low level thermal stability.  There has been 
recent research on the impact of low level thermal stability on winds in the rotor layer [3,4].  The overall 
impact of such events on the wind resource offshore depends on how often they occur, which remains to 
be determined. Their predictability depends on whether the larger synoptic scale situation leads to 
conditions that make such small scale events more likely, and if any synoptic scale precursor conditions 
can be identified.   A detailed investigation of low level jet formation and its precursors is ongoing.  
 In addition,  the occurrence of negative shear conditions across the rotor layer may be more frequent 
than expected, as shown by the preliminary analysis of data from NASA-DAWN1 Lidar, and  the NOAA 
marine met stations designated CHLV2 and NDBC 44010.  This has significant implications for rotor 
design, production estimates, and power forecasting.  Further investigation of this phenomenon is 
ongoing.

Regulatory Position C.1 covers the selection and use of locks to protect National Security Information, Restricted Data, and Formally Restricted Data and references 10 CFR 95.25(a).
10 CFR 95.25(a) states:
(a) Secret matter, while unattended or not in actual use, must be stored in--
(1) A safe, steel file cabinet, or safe-type steel file container that has an automatic unit locking mechanism. All such receptacles will be accorded supplemental protection during non-working hours; or

The drawers of the container must be held securely so their contents cannot be removed without forcing open the drawer. SECRET Storage. SECRET material shall be stored in a GSA-approved security container, an approved vault, or closed area. Supplemental controls are required for storage in closed areas. The following additional storage methods may be used until October 1, 2012:

Re: Draft Regulatory Guide DG-5027
Dear Ms. Blady:
The Virginia Radioactive Materials Program (VRMP) has reviewed this draft guidance on "General
Use of Locks" and provides the following comments for the NRC's review:
1. The VRPM recommends verbiage be included in Section B, "Discussion" that licensees under the
Part 37 regulations are currently in-line with the security requirements and that this guidance is to
help licensees understand the complexity of locks that can be used.
2. The VRMP does not understand the following statement made on page 18: "However, voluntarily
using the subject matter in the guidance may change a licensee's plan such that the NRC review
may be required under the provisions of 10 CFR 37.43....". The security plan required under 10
CFR 37.43 should always be part of a license inspection and not just subject to review based upon
the licensee using this guidance document on locking devices. The VRMP recommends removing
this statement from the guidance.
3. The VRMP recommends that discussion regarding Part 37 licensees be separated from licensees in
Part 50, 70 and 73. The VRMP contends that Part 37 licensees may believe they are required to
follow this guidance and/or amend their license to commit to this guidance even though that is not
required in the licensing requirements for Part 37.
The VRMP thanks you for your consideration of our comments and if you have any questions please
contact Mike Welling at 804-864-8168 or mike.welling(&vdh.virginia.gov.
Mike Welling
Director Radioactive Materials Program

Dear Ms. Bladey:
On behalf of the nuclear energy industry, the Nuclear Energy Institute (NEI)' appreciates the opportunity to
provide comments on the Draft Regulatory Guide DG-5027; "General Use of Locks in Protection and Control of
Facilities and Special Nuclear Materials, Classified Matter, and Safeguards Information," 80 FR 53 (Jan. 2,
2015) (Docket ID NRC-2014-0276).
The purpose of this Draft Regulatory Guide (DG-5027) is to describe to the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory
Commission (NRC) staff, the methods and procedures acceptable for the selection, use, and control of locking
devices in the protection of areas, facilities, and specific types of information. Our overarching comment is
that there appears to be no risk-informed graded approach employed with regard to the level or type of
material being protected and that the guidance may not present a clear understanding of applicability.
NEI is the organization responsible for establishing unified nuclear industry policy on matters affecting the nuclear energy industry, including
the regulatory aspects of generic operational and technical issues. NEI's members include all utilities licensed to operate commercial nuclear
power plants in the United States, nuclear plant designers, major architect/engineering firms, fuel fabrication facilities, materials licensees,
and other organizations and individuals involved in the nuclear energy industry.

applicant applied to NRC for an extension to its operating license, extending operation for an

alternative is to grant the 20-year extension.

premise that environmental impacts of most nuclear power plant license renewals are similar.

renewal. EPA acknowledges that mitigation measures that are un-related to nuclear safety and
security cannot be included in the NRC license. This includes, but is not limited to, diesel
emissions reduction measures. However, because we find these measures to be value-added, we
continue to recomnend them to the applicant for any construction activities and include them in

DOCKET NUMBER NRC-2013-0178 Byron Nuclear Power Plant Relicensing

I oppose the license renewal for the Byron Plant because it is a not environmentally sound and is a serious threat to human health and safety.

I am a 72 year old male retiree, residing ca. 20 miles south-southwest of the facility. I have family members--including children--living 5-10 miles from the plant and I fear for their health and safety. Research reveals increased cancer risk for those living within 10 miles of nuclear power plants and other studies show that nuclear workers have a greater risk of cancer than the survivors of Hiroshima/Nagasaki bombings in WWII. Nuclear power plants emit radiation daily and more serious releases occur during refueling.

There is no safe level of radiation. The health consequences of exposure to continued low levels are worse than one high level exposure.

Exelon's competence in operating Byron is questionable, as indicated in "Toxic Management Erodes Safety at 'World's Safest' Nuclear Plant" by Dreux Richard (The Japan Times, March 11, 2013). The allegations in this article have not been adequately or publicly addressed by Exelon or the NRC in my estimation, and the suggestion by the NRC Public Relations staff that I dig through reams of documents to see if the situation was adequately dealt with leaves me cold. An associate of mine was a career employee at Byron who took early retirement out of frustration and disgust, stating, "Nuclear power is fine--if its done right." (And also indicates that most of the above mentioned ariticle is true).

I recommend tthat the NRC institute policies and procedures to assure that Exelon and other plant operators maintain management practices that do not intimidate employees who are trying to ensure safe operation of nuclear power plants, and to inform the public of violations of said policies and remediation of said violations. Toxic management does not assure safety for the health of the environment, the public, and staff.

The alternatives to the renewal of the Byron license are clear and viable: Wind, solar and other renewable energy sources are now environmentally and economically sound. It is time to let this Nuclear Neanderthal technology die a hopefully swift death.

Thank you.

On behalf of UCS, I submitted FOIA/PA-2015-0082 seeking Final Safety Analysis Report records received after October 1, 2001, by the NRC from all nuclear plant owners, including the Byron licensee. By letter dated January 7, 2015, the NRC administratively closed my request. By email dated December 30, 2014, the NRC staff notified me that the estimated page count for the requested records was 448,000 just from Region IV. That email estimated approximately 4,000 pages per FSAR per reactor with multiple updates per reactor since October 1, 2001 -- accounting for the hundreds of thousands of pages per region.

By withholding this vast quantity of FSAR material from the public, the NRC is significantly impairing our ability to review and comment on licensing request such as this one for Byron. The FSARs describe the safety-related structures, systems, and components at the plant and further describe their role in preventing or mitigating design basis transients and accidents.

NRC regulation 10 CFR 50.59 requires licensees to screen proposed modifications and changes to plant operating procedures to see whether the proposed changes might reduce safety margins approved by the NRC in a significant way. If so, the changes cannot be made until after the NRC reviews and formally approves them. The 10 CFR 50.59 screenings and evaluations rely heavily on information in the FSARs. The FSARs are also extensively used by NRC's reviewers when evaluating licensee requests for licensing actions.

As stated above, by withholding hundreds of thousands of pages of FSARs from the public, the NRC is significantly impairing our ability to participating in licensing proceedings in a meaningful away. The licensees and the NRC staff rely heavily on the FSAR information while preparing and reviewing requests for licensing actions, but the NRC's withholding prevents the public from reviewing this information.

The hundreds of thousands of pages of vital information being withheld by the NRC staff is being done so improperly. Entire FSARs, such as the recent updates for Beaver Valley Unit 2 and Watts Bar Unit 2, were made publicly available by the NRC in their entirety. This demonstrates that FSARs do not contain classified, safeguards, or sensitive information that must be withheld from public disclosure.

The NRC should not approve this licensing request at Byron until after the agency makes all the FSAR information for Byron publicly available and gives the public sufficient time to review this information. Failing to do so transforms this licensing process into a mockery of justice.

comment_text: I recommend that a level of prevailing severy level (high, medium or low) be added to the HPMS "Cracking %" reporting requirement to be used as one of the pavement condition rating threshold in the regulation. This will help better describe the severity of the cracking present in each HPMS reporting section ( 0.1 mile in lenght), therefore resulting in a more accurate assessment of the actual pavement condition in each HPMS reproting section. For example, a HPMS section may have less than 5% of cracking on the surface but the severity of that cracking may be high based on prevaling standards, while another HPMS section may have 20% cracking with low severity. For me the section with < 5% cracking may be consider poor based on the severity of its cracking instead of good based on the current criteria included in the proposed regulation.

Some comments on Pavement Condition Measures

International Roughness Index (IRI) has long been part of the HPMS but as a measure of roughness, it should not be the sole pavement performance measure.

In or around 1995 a pavement was rated as poor if the IRI was greater than 220 but this was for the non-interstate routes whereas the threshold for the interstate routes was set at 170. Reference past issues of Highway Statistics to find this metric. Now the proposal is to set the threshold at 170 outside of all urban areas that have less than one million population and then at 220 inside the urban areas that have more than one million population for the non-interstate NHS. A pavement with an IRI between 170 and 220 may be rough but it is not necessarily in need of rehabilitation or maintenance. A PCI rating may be a better indicator of that since it has to do with condition and not only roughness.

According to the statewide Local Streets and Roads needs assessment done in California, about 80-90% of the pavement ratings are done in PCI (Pavement Condition Index) or similar, which is pretty much all the cities and counties that reported to the needs assessment survey.

But how many agencies measure IRI? It is principally the state DOT that has to assume this responsibility.

The burden and time and cost of measuring the IRI on all of the NHS and the samples of minor arterial and collector streets seems to be a greater challenge than collecting PCI from the MPOs. PCI is almost always easier to obtain and less costly than IRI and PCI is standardized under the specification ASTM D 6433 (2007).

As for the HPMS connection, PSR is reported in the HPMS and PCI can be converted to PSR. This is not to say that it isnt as easy to create one more data item and report the PCI.

In 2014 dollars, California has to spend 3-4 million annually to collect the IRI. The faulting, rutting and cracking will be about another 1-2 million annually. Nationally, this could run $40-50 million every year to comply with the reporting for the IRI, faulting, rutting and cracking along with the person-hours of contract administration since most of this work is done under contract.

It may be worthwhile to reexamine the business case for using PCI as a pavement performance measure.

My recommendation is to incorporate a clause into this rule that promotes the support of small businesses across the nation, within each state and county, so as to encourage the economic growth within each region that will already be given a boost if this rule is passed due to the increase in demand for civil contractors as well as the new positions the DOT will be required to hire in support of the inspection and construction accounting associated with each new project. I believe it is imperative that this new rule doesnt end up catering to the Oligopoly or even Monopoly that the exists with the big general contractors such as Las Vegas Asphalt Paving in Las Vegas, NV who currently consumes the majority of asphalt paving in Clark County. Furthermore, some level of marketing for the availability of this type of work to current small business general contractors should be included for this feat.
I fully support this new proposed rule as it takes a major step in the right direction to correcting the overload of renovations and new roads and bridges that this growing nation requires. I support the initiative to enable the DOT as the enforcer and authority to issue fines to those regions who are in violation of this new rule. I also support the given target time periods for renovations as reasonable. The 2-4 year period is more than sufficient, as long as the language is explicit in that reasonable time be allotted for weather delays or other uncontrollable circumstances so that no fines be levied for such delays. I do feel that the cost benefits might be a bit understated. Certainly places that are experiencing high traffic volumes that are given funding for the widening of the roads or where new bridges provide access quicker to areas will benefit the local economies as well the social mentality from lessening their daily commute. Not to mention the superordinate goal of keeping cars on the road less to bring down CO2 emissions.
